questions: Do you also have a rash?
Are you experiencing joint or muscle pain?
Have you recently traveled or been exposed to mosquito bites?
Do you have chills or sweating?
Have you had the fever for more than 1-2 days?
flows.redFlagGuidance: This may need urgent care — seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or new ones appear.
flows.nonUrgentAdvice: Stay hydrated, rest, monitor temperature. See doctor if it persists beyond 3 days.
nonUrgentConditions: Viral infection, heat exhaustion, mild flu
flows.summary: Based on your symptoms, you may be experiencing a mild viral illness or heat-related condition. This is not a diagnosis. Please consult a medical professional if symptoms worsen or persist.

questions: Did the joint pain start recently?
Is the pain in more than one joint?
Have you had a recent fever, rash, or mosquito bites?
Do the joints feel stiff in the morning or after rest?
Do you have any swelling, redness, or warmth around the joints?
flows.redFlagText: Severe swelling, high fever, inability to move the joint, or pain post-injury
flows.redFlagGuidance: Your symptoms may indicate a serious condition. Please seek urgent medical care immediately.
nonUrgentConditions: Chikungunya, dengue-related joint pain, post-viral arthritis, osteoarthritis, overuse injury

questions: Have you had the headache for more than 1-2 days?
Is your headache predominantly one-sided (including behind the eyes) rather than generalized?
Do you feel nauseated or sensitive to light or sound?
Have you recently spent time in the sun or skipped meals?
Do you have a history of high blood pressure or migraines?
flows.redFlagText: Sudden severe headache, vision changes, weakness, confusion, or headache with fever and stiff neck
flows.redFlagGuidance: Your symptoms may be serious. Please seek urgent medical care, especially if this is your worst headache or it came on suddenly.
nonUrgentConditions: Dehydration, tension headache, migraine, viral illness, mild heat exhaustion

questions: Have you been feeling fatigued for more than a few days?
Are you sleeping well at night?
Have you recently been ill (e.g., flu, viral infection)?
Are you eating regularly and drinking enough fluids?
Do you have any chronic health conditions (e.g., diabetes, thyroid)?
flows.redFlagText: Persistent fatigue combined with thirst and frequent urination.
flows.redFlagGuidance: May indicate uncontrolled blood sugar. Please see a healthcare provider.
nonUrgentConditions: Post-viral fatigue, anemia, poor sleep hygiene, stress, mild dehydration, low vitamin or iron levels

questions: Is the pain located in a specific area (upper, lower, left, or right side)?
Is the pain constant?
Have you had any nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel movements?
For women: Are you currently on your period or has your period been late?
Have you eaten any questionable food or had stomach issues recently?
flows.redFlagText: Severe pain, high fever, persistent vomiting, blood in stool or vomit, or pain localized to lower right side
flows.redFlagGuidance: These symptoms could suggest appendicitis or another urgent condition. Please seek medical care immediately.
nonUrgentConditions: Indigestion, gastritis, mild food poisoning, menstrual cramps, constipation

questions: Has the rash appeared recently and/or spread?
Is the rash itchy, painful, or burning?
Do you also have a fever, joint pain, or eye redness?
Have you recently used a new product (soap, lotion, detergent)?
Do you have any known allergies or recent insect bites?
flows.redFlagText: Rash with high fever, blistering, swelling of lips/eyes, or shortness of breath
flows.redFlagGuidance: This may indicate a serious allergic or infectious reaction. Please go to the nearest health facility immediately.
nonUrgentConditions: Mild viral rash (Zika, dengue), allergic reaction, contact dermatitis, heat rash, scabies

questions: Have you vomited more than 3 times in the last 24 hours?
Are you able to keep down any fluids or food?
Do you also have fever, diarrhea, or abdominal pain?
Have you eaten outside recently or noticed anyone else sick around you?
Are you feeling dizzy or light-headed when standing?
flows.redFlagText: Persistent vomiting (more than 6–8x/day), signs of dehydration, blood in vomit, or confusion
flows.redFlagGuidance: These symptoms could signal dehydration or a more serious condition. Please seek urgent medical attention.
nonUrgentConditions: Viral gastroenteritis, food poisoning, motion sickness, pregnancy, stress

questions: Have you had diarrhea more than 3 times in the last 24 hours?
Is there blood or mucus in the stool?
Do you have a fever, vomiting, or stomach cramps?
Have you recently eaten outside or drunk untreated water?
Are you able to stay hydrated or keep fluids down?
flows.redFlagText: Bloody stools, high fever, signs of dehydration (dry mouth, dizziness, low urine output)
flows.redFlagGuidance: These may be signs of a more serious infection or dehydration. Please see a doctor immediately.
nonUrgentConditions: Mild food poisoning, viral gastroenteritis, diet-related bowel upset
flows.summary: You may have a mild stomach infection or dietary upset. Stay hydrated and monitor. This is not a diagnosis. Seek care if symptoms worsen.

questions: Does the shortness of breath occur at rest?
Do you have any known heart or lung conditions (e.g., asthma)?
Are you also experiencing chest pain, cough, or fever?
Is the environment hot or poorly ventilated?
Do you use any medications or inhalers regularly?
flows.redFlagText: Sudden breathlessness, chest pain, blue lips, confusion, or fainting
flows.redFlagGuidance: These could indicate a serious heart or lung condition. Seek emergency care immediately.
nonUrgentConditions: Mild asthma flare-up, anxiety-related breathing, heat exhaustion
flows.summary: Symptoms may reflect mild breathing issue or heat exhaustion. Seek medical help if symptoms escalate. This is not a diagnosis.

questions: Have you done any physical activity recently?
Do you have a fever, chills, or joint pain as well?
Are you staying hydrated in the heat?
Is the pain localized to one area?
Does the pain improve with rest or gentle movement?
flows.redFlagText: Muscle pain with weakness, swelling, high fever, dark urine
flows.redFlagGuidance: These could be signs of serious infection or muscle breakdown. Seek urgent care.
nonUrgentConditions: Viral infection, heat-related fatigue, overexertion, minor strain
flows.summary: Muscle pain may be due to recent exertion, viral illness, or dehydration. Monitor at home. This is not a diagnosis. Consult a doctor if it worsens.

questions: Did the redness start suddenly?
Is only one eye affected?
Do you have any discharge (pus, tears)?
Have you recently had flu-like symptoms or fever?
Is your vision blurred or affected?
flows.redFlagText: Vision changes or strong eye pain
flows.redFlagGuidance: Seek immediate care from a medical provider or eye specialist
flows.nonUrgentAdvice: Apply cool compresses, wash hands often, avoid eye rubbing; monitor for worsening symptoms
nonUrgentConditions: Allergic conjunctivitis, viral conjunctivitis, dry eyes, irritation from dust
flows.summary: Your symptoms may be due to a mild eye irritation or conjunctivitis. Avoid touching your eyes and monitor your symptoms. If pain worsens or vision changes, consult a doctor. This is not a diagnosis.

questions: Is the itching all over your body?
Is there a visible rash or skin change?
Have you used any new soaps, creams, or eaten anything unusual?
Did you recently get bitten by insects or spend time outdoors?
Is the itching worse at night?
flows.redFlagText: Intense itching with yellowing eyes/skin or swelling
flows.redFlagGuidance: Seek prompt care to rule out liver issues or allergic reaction
flows.nonUrgentAdvice: Use fragrance-free moisturizer, avoid scratching, monitor for rash or swelling
nonUrgentConditions: Bug bites, eczema, contact dermatitis, fungal infections
flows.summary: Mild itching is common and often resolves on its own. Try moisturizing and avoid triggers. Seek care if symptoms worsen. This is not a diagnosis.

questions: Have you had the cough for more than 2 weeks?
Are you coughing up mucus (of any color)?
Do you have chest pain or shortness of breath?
Have you had a recent cold or fever?
Are you exposed to smoke or dust regularly?
flows.redFlagText: Cough lasting >2 weeks with blood or shortness of breath
flows.redFlagGuidance: Seek medical attention for further testing or chest imaging
flows.nonUrgentAdvice: Stay hydrated, use lozenges or warm teas, avoid smoke; monitor for worsening symptoms
nonUrgentConditions: Allergies, post-viral irritation, mild bronchitis, acid reflux
flows.summary: A cough can linger after colds or irritation. Stay hydrated and monitor. If symptoms persist or worsen, consult a doctor. This is not a diagnosis

questions: Do you urinate more than 8 times a day?
Are you waking up during the night to urinate?
Have you recently increased your fluid intake?
Do you drink a lot of sugary drinks like soda, juice, or sweetened tea?
Do you also feel thirsty often?
flows.redFlagText: Urinating more than 8 times a day with persistent thirst and fatigue.
flows.redFlagGuidance: Seek immediate medical evaluation to rule out uncontrolled diabetes or a urinary tract infection.
flows.nonUrgentAdvice: Track your fluid intake and bathroom visits. Avoid sugary drinks and monitor for other symptoms like fatigue or weight loss.
flows.summary: You’re experiencing frequent urination, which may be linked to early diabetes or increased sugar intake. Please consider a blood sugar screening, especially if you also feel thirsty or tired.

questions: Are you drinking more than 8 glasses of water or fluids daily?
Do you sweat a lot during the day?
Are you also urinating more frequently?
Do you feel weak or tired?
Have you experienced recent weight loss?
flows.redFlagText: Excessive thirst with frequent urination and sudden weight loss.
flows.redFlagGuidance: Urgent screening for diabetes is recommended. Visit a health center for a glucose test.
flows.nonUrgentAdvice: Stay hydrated with water, avoid sweetened beverages, and track how long the thirst persists.
flows.summary: Persistent thirst, especially if paired with frequent urination or fatigue, may be an early warning of diabetes. A blood sugar test is strongly advised.
